Summary: I never saw anything at the time of event. In a photo taken, I see 3 blurred white lines (contrails) in sky. Photo is 1/1600 second, so the objects speed is incredibly fast.
trends: There have been 7 other sightings in Lawrence
There were no other sightings in Lawrence on or around January 23rd 2010
This sighting has never been favorited.
divs: sighting detailsi did not notice the objects in person. it was a bright sunny winter day with snow everywhere, so i had sunglasses on. i was shooting my child and friends as they sled down hill toward me at the bottom. a couple weeks later, i finally had time to load the shots into my computer and sort the best shots. i noticed the 3 white flashes across the sky, but didn't give it much thought. but, seeing it again, i decided to look at my metadata for the photo. when i saw shutter speed was 1\1600th of a second, i became suspicious. a plane would have been frozen in place. like i said, i never saw anything with my eyes. but, the photographic evidence is striking. if i had shot at a slow shutter, i would have shrugged it off as planes. it's as if the object traveled across the sky at a blistering speed, and my camera captured it as the lens opened and shut. the fact that the 3 white lines are half an inch long, traveling in same direction, with a shutter that was open 1\1600th of a second just defies imagination. it would take a one or 2 second exposure (camera on tripod) for a commercial jet at 500 mph to leave a half inch blur in same scene. fyi, i was shooting at iso 100 at f\5.6, which explains why the sky is not in focus (short depth of field). it was with a nikon d700, nikon 70-200mm vr lens shot at 102mm focal length, highest rez nikon raw 14 bit. none of the other photos i took has this phenomenon, even taken from exact position shooting in exact direction. answer to questions: 1. i was at bottom of hill at andover high school shooting up at kids sledding, revealing blue sky above them. i am shooting toward west south west direction. (3:02:31 pm, january 23, 2010). 2. i first noticed the objects while viewing photos on my computer, i shoot in raw, so i have to put them into adobe lightroom to make into jpg. the photo i am sending is unretouched sky. 3. first assumed white blurs were falling stars or meteors, something with great speed that naked eye in daylight would not see. 4. i can only judge it's actions by photo, appear to travel left to right across sky. 5. not visible in any other photo from that day.
